text: well most the time uh most times when
I'm asked that question it deals
specifically with legislation what's the
biggest thing you ever did in that
respect and there are quite a few and I
try not to select any perhaps
illustrative was the major clean air
bill that I uh was a principal
supporter and author of in 1990 it was a
very contentious Bill took years and
years of effort um and a very long
legislative process and I uh I devoted a
lot of my life to it uh uh that probably
in legislative terms was I don't know if
it was the most important but it was the
most comprehensive and major Bill
outside of that uh uh I tend to talk
about two things first my work in
Northern Ireland uh I spent a total of
about 5 years uh cheered three separate
sets of proceedings uh I wasn't there
for five years non-stop I coming and
going and uh but for the most part I was
there for long periods of time during
that stretch and uh we just uh in the
past month have celebrated the 10th
anniversary of the so-called good Friday
agreement the peace agreement which
resulted from one of the negotiations
which I cheered that was very
significant uh I I I like Northern
Ireland I like the people I like the
place uh I still go there quite a bit uh
uh I serve as the chancellor of the
Queens University in Northern Ireland
which is a large institution of Higher
Learning there uh and so that takes me
back and other in other capacities I go
back probably three or four times a year
I like to take my children there to give
five young children to give them some
sense of uh what was important in my
life uh the other thing that I I spend a
lot of my time on and that I'm most
proud of is when I left the Senate I
created a scholarship program for needy
students from Maine started small uh I I
got started in a funny way I I had
raised money in preparation to for reele
ction and then I decided not to run uh
and so I wrote to every contributor and
I said you can have your money back if
you want it but if you leave it with me
I'm going to use it for scholarships uh
and about half took the money back and
about half left it with me that got us
started and I've since spent that was uh
13 years ago and I've spent a great deal
of time in the innovating 13 years
raising money and we now provide a
scholarship to graduate from each public
High School in Maine 130 of them each
year so we we've have a lot of kids have
gone through the process and I spend a
lot of time at it and it's very
heartening uh to see it because I myself
uh as I mentioned earlier in the
interview uh I wasn't certain I was
going to go to college uh my parents had
absolutely no money my father wasn't
working at the time and I got a lot of
help from a lot of people some
scholarship assistance a lot of work
effort Bowden College which I went to a
great Institution to which I owe much of
uh what I've been able to do in life uh
they helped me out with a lot of jobs so
I kind of work two three four jobs all
the time while I was in school uh and it
not only helped me get through school
but it taught me uh I think a good work
ethic so uh the scholarship uh fund
means a lot to me I I I meet with these
students each year and uh I see in a lot
of them where I was at the time
uncertain
insecure don't really know what you're
going to do with life but there's a
potential
